stream_context.summary: Kaze reviews and begins integrating Biobak’s major visual/structural overhaul of Course 11 (Oily Boily Bay/Power Plant), fixing import/material/render issues, and planning next steps like rebuilding collision and addressing an area crash. He also previews a new movement tweak (higher bounce when holding A after stomping Goombas) and outlines a plan to ship a smaller Course 1-only demo to gather focused playtest feedback on camera and physics via a structured form.
stream_context.significance_reason: Major art/level overhaul arrives from Biobak and gets validated in-engine; Kaze also articulates a concrete playtest-driven demo strategy (Course 1 only) and shows a new movement mechanic intended to modernize Mario 64 controls.

findings.summary: Kaze proposes releasing a new, smaller demo containing only Course 1 (instead of maintaining multiple courses in a demo) specifically to collect focused playtest feedback on camera behavior and movement physics across varied geometry (walls, poles, slides, open spaces).
findings.quote: The idea would be that I get a lot of playtest data to tweak all the little variables so that everything’s perfect.

findings.summary: To support the Course 1 demo playtest, Kaze plans to ship a feedback form (Google Doc) so players can report what they like/dislike about controls, camera, and feel in a structured way.

Course 11 integration reveals that collision was authored before Biobak’s rework; Kaze calls it a major mistake and concludes he must rebuild the collision map after the final geometry to avoid mismatches (missing entrances, confusing navigation) and crashes.
findings.quote: I shouldn’t have done a collision map before Biobak was done. Biggest mistake of my life.

findings.summary: A sub-area in Course 11 currently crashes, preventing Kaze from reviewing Area 6; he plans to fix the collision and crash off-stream, then continue testing areas and updating objects.

Biobak’s Course 11 rework shifts the visual tone: more vibrant color palette, revised lighting logic (removing “single sun” assumption), and a “brutalist” Bowser Tower/office vibe; Kaze strongly approves the new mood and readability.
findings.quote: This is like so vibrant… This tower looks so cool.

findings.summary: Kaze identifies rendering-order/material pipeline issues: transparent decal layering (layer 6 vs 5) and the need for world-aligned step rendering; he suggests swapping layer conventions across the game so decals don’t render after transparent surfaces.

Kaze troubleshoots missing/incorrect material settings (fog, cycle settings, VColor-based materials), and notes that the game uses camera-based culling partitions (east/north/south/west) but can’t exploit them as aggressively as linear games like Crash Bandicoot.

Biobak includes a factory “easter egg room” concept with an NPC Koopa on a hamster wheel and environmental reactions (lights flicker, pipes shut off) when interacted with; Kaze discusses how to prevent trapping the player and how to gate/telegraph the secret.

Biobak’s underground section includes many asset variants (e.g., 11 versions) to keep lighting/UVs consistent per context; Kaze says it’s doable but annoying and considers handling it via object/vertex-data reuse rather than importing full duplicates.
Kaze previews an N64 workflow improvement device (a flashcart/debug setup) intended to speed iteration for real-hardware testing/development.
findings.quote: This will make N64 development a good amount faster.

findings.summary: Kaze adds/shows a movement tweak: after stomping a Goomba, holding A produces a higher rebound and restores some midair control, aiming to evoke 2D Mario bounce behavior and make movement feel smoother.
findings.quote: If you hold the A button, you jump higher. And you regain some control of Mario.

findings.summary: Kaze argues that choosing colors should be emotion-driven rather than rule-driven; he criticizes simplistic “color theory” recipes as non-empirical and often misapplied in art direction decisions.
findings.quote: The point… is you think of an emotion and then you think about how you can use the tools in your arsenal to evoke this emotion.

findings.summary: Kaze rejects democratic design-by-poll for core content decisions, saying centralized direction produces better results than letting the crowd decide what gets added.
findings.quote: I do not believe in democracy… I genuinely believe me making every single decision ever is better than democracy for everyone involved.

findings.summary: Kaze encounters toolchain friction moving to newer Blender/Fast64 versions: user presets appear missing/relocated, controls differ, and this slows iteration while importing/exporting course assets.

Testing uncovers gameplay/engine edge cases to fix later, including a softlock where Mario’s safe position updates incorrectly when hanging on a bench and a perceived one-frame delay/inertia change after reordering frame updates tied to collision/displacement logic.

biobak.summary: Delivered a substantial Course 11 visual rework: more vibrant palette, revised walkway coloring (less “Wario-ish”), updated containers/cranes, new Bowser Tower ‘brutalist’ architecture, and a more cohesive industrial ‘power plant’ mood.
Optimized/cleaned the level structure (material consolidation, UV updates) and reduced polygon count (Kaze notes ~1,700 fewer triangles vs the older version).

Proposed/implemented factory setpieces and an easter-egg room concept (Koopa hamster-wheel NPC, interactive factory reactions like flickering lights/pipes turning off) designed to feel diegetic to the environment.

Provided underground asset variants and detailed notes (elevator doors moving only at stops, hydraulic platform visual depth via extending sides/accordion effect, cable/door gap alignment), implying a more systemic approach to environmental believability.
Suggested multiple subtle ambient animations (light pulsing, treadmill/texture scrolling, environmental motion) to make static geometry feel alive without heavy gameplay impact.

badub.summary: A composer message is referenced: if a sub-area lacks unique music, it should use one of Badub’s bonus tracks; Kaze starts to preview a track but is interrupted by level/crash issues.

findings.summary: Suggested quickly exporting/testing Biobak’s remodel in-game to validate it early; also tried to help locate Blender user preset storage paths after Kaze’s presets appeared missing in Blender 4.x.
Acted as real-time troubleshooting support during toolchain friction (Blender version/presets), reinforcing the stream-as-collaborative debug environment.
Reacted positively to Kaze’s anti-poll/anti-democracy stance on design decisions, reinforcing Kaze’s preference for strong auteur direction.
findings.quote: You’re so real for that Kaze.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The point of what you’re making is… you think of an emotion and then you think about how you can use the tools in your arsenal to evoke this emotion.
memorable_quotes.context: Rant about art direction and rejecting simplistic ‘color theory’ rules in favor of mood-first decision making.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I do not believe in democracy.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze rejects community polls deciding what features/content get added, framing strong centralized direction as better for the project.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I shouldn’t have done a collision map before Biobak was done. Biggest mistake of my life.
memorable_quotes.context: Lesson learned while integrating Biobak’s large geometry rework: collision must come after layout stabilizes.

key_stories.title: Integrating Biobak’s Oily Boily Bay (Course 11) overhaul
key_stories.summary: Kaze receives and reviews Biobak’s revamped Course 11, praising the vibrant palette, brutalist tower/office theme, and industrial detailing. Importing it surfaces render/material issues, outdated collision, and an area crash that blocks full playthrough testing.
key_stories.challenge: Large geometry changes broke alignment with existing collision and exposed material/render-order problems; one area crashes, preventing full validation.
key_stories.process: Kaze exports/imports into the game, compares changelog items, fixes obvious material flags (fog/cycle/VColor), identifies decal-layer ordering issues, and notes that collision must be rebuilt post-rework.
key_stories.outcome: Visual direction is accepted and largely working in-engine; Kaze plans off-stream collision rebuild + crash fix before further testing and a potential main-channel showcase.

key_stories.title: Course 1-only demo as a camera/physics testbed
key_stories.summary: Kaze decides the next public demo should be limited to Course 1, not a multi-course slice, so it can be iterated frequently without maintaining multiple levels. He wants structured playtest data to tune camera and movement variables.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining multiple playable courses in a demo slows iteration; Kaze needs reliable feedback on camera/physics across many movement scenarios.
key_stories.process: He outlines publishing a Course 1 demo alongside a feedback document to capture what feels good/bad about controls, camera behavior, and physics edge cases.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete community playtest plan emerges, positioning Course 1 as the project’s ongoing ‘calibration’ level.
key_stories.key_quote: Course one has a lot of stuff that I need to test with the camera.

key_stories.title: Collision authored too early
key_stories.summary: While testing the new Course 11 geometry, Kaze realizes the collision map was built before Biobak’s final layout, causing missing paths/entrances and confusion. He calls this an avoidable pipeline error.
key_stories.challenge: Collision no longer matches remodeled geometry, increasing bugs and slowing validation.
key_stories.process: Kaze flags the collision rebuild as a next step and decides to handle it off-stream together with fixing the crashing area.
key_stories.outcome: Pipeline lesson: finalize layout/art pass first, then lock collision; collision rebuild becomes the immediate blocker task.

key_stories.title: Modernizing Mario feel with small movement hacks
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrates a new Goomba-stomp behavior where holding A yields a higher bounce and returns control, echoing 2D Mario. He frames it as part of a broader push to remove ‘dead frames’ and make actions flow together.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla Mario 64 feel has input-dead frames and less fluid chaining; Kaze wants a more modern, satisfying movement loop while staying Mario-like.
key_stories.process: He tweaks post-stomp behavior and highlights how additional hacks (dive/double-jump etc.) make it hard to return to vanilla controls.
key_stories.outcome: Another concrete ‘feel’ improvement is added to the movement kit and earmarked for playtest feedback via the planned demo.
key_stories.key_quote: You can’t go back to vanilla Mario 64 after playing with these.

key_stories.title: Toolchain friction: Blender/Fast64 presets and version drift
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggles after opening assets in a newer Blender version: navigation controls differ and user presets appear missing/relocated. The confusion interrupts momentum during import/debug and prompts back-and-forth with Lilaa about where presets are stored.
key_stories.challenge: Lost/relocated presets and changed controls slow down integration and troubleshooting.
key_stories.process: Kaze attempts to locate preset directories, toggles Fast64, and ultimately proceeds without presets to keep moving.
key_stories.outcome: Short-term workaround (manual setup) but an unresolved pipeline question remains: how to port/share presets reliably across versions.

open_questions.context: Kaze plans a Course 1-only demo plus a Google Doc for structured feedback on camera and physics, intending frequent updates without maintaining multiple levels.
questions: What exact camera issues are you trying to validate in Course 1 (lock-on, wall-jumps between parallel walls, poles, FOV, occlusion, auto-rotate, manual override)?
Which movement/physics variables are you prepared to tweak based on feedback (air control, friction, coyote time, dive/double-jump timing, slope handling, bonk behavior)?
How will you triage and quantify the playtest feedback (tagging, reproductions, clips, versioning) so it turns into actionable tuning tasks?
Will you run closed tests first (trusted testers) or go straight to public, and how will you avoid contradictory feedback paralysis?

open_questions.context: One sub-area in Course 11 currently crashes, blocking access to Area 6 during testing.
questions: Which area is crashing (ID), and what symptoms/logs point to the cause (memory, display lists, behavior scripts, geo layout, collision pointer)?
Is the crash tied to the new assets/import (Fast64 export), to outdated collision/warp nodes, or to level script/area transitions?
What is your debugging workflow for these crashes on emulator vs real hardware?

open_questions.context: Kaze regrets building collision before Biobak’s geometry stabilized and plans to redo it off-stream.
questions: What’s the intended pipeline going forward: blockout → collision → art pass, or blockout → art pass → final collision?
Who ‘owns’ collision authoring (Kaze, Biobak, shared), and what tools/validation steps prevent mismatches?
How do you ensure gameplay surfaces remain readable and fair once visuals get denser (especially in Course 11’s busy industrial spaces)?

open_questions.context: Kaze says the game’s layer convention should be swapped so transparent decals don’t render after transparent surfaces, and mentions world-aligned step rendering implications.
questions: What is the current render layer scheme across the hack, and why did it evolve that way?
How widespread would a global layer swap be, and what would it risk breaking (water, windows, fog planes, particles)?
Do you have a test scene/checklist to verify correct render ordering after changes?

open_questions.context: Biobak’s plan includes a Koopa hamster-wheel NPC, lights flickering, pipes turning off, and a hidden access hole; Kaze considers gating and preventing the player from getting stuck.
questions: What’s the final intended player path to discover the easter egg (visibility, hints, gating, reward)?
How will the ‘factory powers down’ effect be implemented technically (global lighting change, screen overlay, per-room material switch, animated textures)?
Will the easter egg be purely flavor, or tie into collectibles/coins/1-ups to justify the space?

open_questions.context: Biobak delivered multiple versions of an underground asset to keep lighting/UVs from looking wrong; Kaze suggests storing vertex data only or switching variants at runtime.
questions: What specifically required 11 variants—unique vertex colors, UV tweaks, or different material setups?
Could a single mesh plus per-instance vertex color overrides work within your engine constraints?
How do you balance per-area visual correctness against ROM size, build complexity, and iteration speed?

open_questions.topic: Movement hack: Goomba stomp ‘hold A’ higher bounce
open_questions.context: Kaze shows a new stomp behavior that increases bounce height and restores control, aiming for 2D-like responsiveness.
questions: What other enemies/objects should share this behavior (Koopas, Shy Guys, etc.), and how do you prevent it from breaking level difficulty?
Is this an optional technique (advanced) or core expected movement, and how will the game teach it?
How does it interact with double jump/dive/other movement hacks and camera framing?

open_questions.topic: Art style consistency for background billboards
open_questions.context: Kaze notes that some background Koopa billboard art feels stylistically inconsistent with the rest of the hack and considers revising faces/linework.
questions: What is the project’s ‘style bible’ for 2D art assets (line thickness, eye style, shading, proportion), and who defines it?
Who created the billboard art originally, and would Biobak/Zeina redo it or adjust it to match other assets?
How important is background art consistency versus shipping levels—what’s the threshold for ‘good enough’?

open_questions.context: Kaze’s user presets appear missing after switching Blender versions; this affects speed and even the ability to share settings with Biobak.
questions: Where are the presets stored across Blender versions in your pipeline, and how will you standardize this for the team?
Should the project pin a specific Blender/Fast64 version to reduce drift, or maintain a migration guide?
Do you need a shared repo/package for presets and export settings so collaborators can match materials reliably?

open_questions.topic: Main-channel rollout plan (Course 11 showcase vs demo)
open_questions.context: Kaze considers showcasing Course 11 visuals on the main channel first to build hype, then releasing the Course 1 demo 2–3 weeks later.
questions: What criteria determine when Course 11 is ‘showcase-ready’ (performance targets, collision done, crashes fixed, camera polish)?
How do you want to sequence marketing beats so the audience understands ‘visual showcase’ vs ‘playtest demo’?
What feedback are you hoping a Course 11 video generates compared to the Course 1 playable demo?
